relation: configure terminal Example: Device# configure terminal
profile flow port-map protocol-name[tcp | udp] port-number Example: Device(config)# profile flow port-map rtsp udp 1051
Enables privileged EXEC mode. Enter your password if prompted.
Configures a user-defined port number by overriding the standard port number for the specified protocol.
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {43427=V1.0.19, 57812=10.0.0.95, 7633=1718, 82665=For instance, you can create an MSP profile where a SIP flow matching payload type 96, bandwidth of 64 kb/s, and an audio codec of G.711 can initiate RSVP bandwidth reservations., 47057=1720, 31307=Video Codec}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {112571=The following EEM script lets the system automatically the H.323 flow matching payload type 96, bandwidth of 64 kb/s, and an audio codec of G.711, and also to provide RSVP bandwidth reservations:, 53404=Device(config-ms-md)# bandwidth 1200, 86928=Device(config)# profile flow port-map rtsp udp 1051, 106078=The following example shows how to manually configure RSVP parameters of bandwidth 1056 kb/s, max burst 3000, and a defending priority 2 that can be applied to a flow:}
textBeforeTable: DETAILED STEPS 4.    end 3.    profile flow port-map protocol-name[tcp | udp] port-number 2.    configure terminal 1.    enable SUMMARY STEPS By default, standard TCP or UDP ports are used for device and flow identification. You can perform the following task to override the standard port numbers and configure user-defined port numbers for the specified protocols. Configuring User-Defined Port Numbers for Protocols Returns to privileged EXEC mode.   Device(config-ms-rsvp)# end   Example: end Step 8 Configures the defending or the preemption priority for the flow.   Device(config-ms-rsvp)# priority defending 2   Example: priority {defending defend-value | premption prempt-value}
textAfterTable: Verifying the MSP Configuration Use the following commands to verify the MSP configuration. You can use the show commands in any order: SUMMARY STEPS 1.    enable 2.    show profile flow 3.    show profile flow statistics [protocol] 4.    show profile device DETAILED STEPS Step 1   enable Enables privileged EXEC mode. Step 2   show profile flow Displays the number of flows that have been identified. Example: Device# show profile flow Source-IP sPort Dest-IP dPort protocol Media Services profile 10.1.1.1 2000 10.2.2.2 2001 UDP msp_service_A 10.1.1.4 3000 10.2.2.4 2001 UDP msp_service_B Step 3   show profile flow statistics [protocol] Displays profile statistics for a given protocol to identify packet drops associated with the protocol, if
